context: Act 2A Chapter 2.2 — Jade's big event. Corporate elites, uncomfortable small talk. Nikko shows up unexpectedly.

lines.text: The Nova Pacifica Grand Ballroom. Crystal chandeliers that cost more than your childhood home. A string quartet playing something classical that makes expensive people nod like they understand it.
You are in a tuxedo. It fits perfectly because someone measured you for it three days ago, which is three more days of tuxedo planning than you have ever experienced.

Jade is in her element. She moves through the crowd like water through a riverbed — touching every bank, never stopping, always flowing toward the next conversation. She is wearing a black dress that costs more than the CRX and she looks like she was born in this room.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: This is Marcus Holt — CEO of Pacific Tire. Marcus, meet our newest driver.

lines.speaker: Marcus Holt
lines.text: Ah, the underground sensation. Jade won't stop talking about you. Tell me — what's it like going from street racing to the big leagues?

choices.text: The cars are faster, but the politics are slower.
It's an honor to represent Apex at this level.

lines.label: holt_laughs
lines.text: Holt laughs — the genuine kind, not the boardroom kind. Jade's eyes flash with approval.

lines.speaker: Marcus Holt
lines.text: I like this one, Jade. Most of your drivers recite press releases. This one has a personality.

lines.label: holt_nods
lines.text: Holt nods. The polite, empty nod of a man who has heard the same answer from a hundred athletes at a hundred galas.

lines.speaker: Marcus Holt
lines.text: Good attitude. Jade, you've trained this one well.

lines.label: holt_interested
lines.speaker: Marcus Holt
lines.text: Ha! Aren't we all. The food here is terrible anyway.
Jade's smile tightens by exactly one millimeter. You're off-script, but at least you're interesting.

lines.label: gala_mingle
lines.text: An hour of handshakes, small talk, and champagne you don't drink. Every conversation follows the same pattern: smile, compliment, business card, promise to meet for lunch that neither party will keep.
You are standing by the window, looking at the city lights, when you hear a voice that doesn't belong in this room.

lines.speaker: Nikko
lines.text: Didn't think they let street rats in here.

Nikko Tanaka. In a suit that's slightly too big — rented, not tailored. His hair is different. His face is thinner. But his eyes are the same — sharp, hungry, carrying a weight that wasn't there before.
He looks out of place the way you feel out of place. Two underground kids in a ballroom full of people who were born above ground.

choices.text: Nikko. What are you doing here?
Good to see you. You look... different.

lines.label: nikko_explains
lines.speaker: Nikko
lines.text: Kessler Racing invited me. Apparently my 'troubled youth narrative' plays well with sponsors. I'm their diversity hire for the season.

lines.speaker: Nikko
lines.text: They don't want me to win. They want me to almost win. Just enough drama to sell ad space.

lines.label: nikko_vulnerable
lines.text: Nikko's guard drops for a fraction of a second. Just a flash — like a card turned over and immediately hidden again.

lines.speaker: Nikko
lines.text: Different. Yeah. That's one word for it.

lines.label: nikko_smirk
lines.text: Nikko almost smiles. Almost. The muscles twitch but the expression doesn't quite land.

lines.speaker: Nikko
lines.text: At least you own it. I feel like an imposter in a rented suit.

lines.label: nikko_confession
lines.text: He takes a glass of champagne from a passing waiter and downs it in one motion. Not celebrating. Medicating.

lines.speaker: Nikko
lines.text: I owe people money. A lot of money. The kind of money that comes with men who know where your family lives.

lines.speaker: Nikko
lines.text: This corporate gig — Kessler — it's the only way I can pay it back. But the contract is a cage. They own my racing, my image, my schedule. I can't even enter an underground event without written permission.

lines.speaker: Nikko
lines.text: I used to drive because I loved it. Now I drive because I have to. There's a difference.

choices.text: We'll figure it out. You're not alone in this.
Welcome to the corporate world. It's all cages.

lines.label: nikko_debt_amount
lines.speaker: Nikko
lines.text: Half a million. Give or take. Gambling debts, mostly. Turns out I'm better at racing than I am at cards.
Half a million dollars. You think about Maya's shop — sixty thousand was life and death for her. Nikko's number is in another universe.

lines.label: nikko_grateful
lines.text: Nikko looks at you. For a long moment. Something behind his eyes shifts — not trust, not yet, but the possibility of trust. The crack in the wall where light might eventually get through.

lines.speaker: Nikko
lines.text: You pulled me out of a burning car once. I never forgot that. Maybe... maybe it's worth trying to be less of a disaster.

lines.speaker: Nikko
lines.text: I don't need a hero. But I could use a friend. I don't have many of those.

lines.label: nikko_agrees
lines.speaker: Nikko
lines.text: At least underground, the cage had bigger bars.
He takes another champagne. You watch the city through the window and neither of you says anything for a while. Two underground racers in a ballroom, pretending they belong.

lines.label: gala_end
lines.text: Jade finds you both twenty minutes later. She looks from you to Nikko and back, and something in her expression recalibrates.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: I see you found a friend. Don't let me interrupt — but remember, cameras are everywhere. Smile for the sponsors.
She melts back into the crowd. The gala swirls on around you — champagne and laughter and money and lies. Two worlds, separated by a dress code.
